result.title: Introduction to competitive programming
result.content:
For those who are new to HKOI / competitive programming, we usually practice our programming skills using online judge platforms.

Good Online Judges

Codeforces (here)

Pros: You can see everyone else's submissions (including mine), regular contests.

Cons: Problemset contains too many problems. Users cannot know the difficulty of the problems easily.

HKOI online judge

Pros: I can see your submissions. (You may ask me to look at / debug your submissions).

Cons: No editorials.

USACO

Pros: Step by step guide to typical problems, good for newbies.

Cons: Strange/old style of submitting solutions (involve file I/O).

Kattis

Pros: Nice UI with a builtin problem difficulty ranking system.

Cons: Pascal is not supported. Cannot search problems by topic.

Where to start?

My suggestion is to start with HKOI online judge first. Begin with the "popular" tasks first to familiarize yourself with the problem format.

After that, practice with those division 2 A/B problems on Codeforces. Learn from others' source codes. You can learn how to write a better program and learn tricks from others.

Solving 10 problems a week can improve your programming skills rapidly within a year. Challenge yourself to Codeforces contest will also help you to do better in real contests like HKOI.

If you have problems, please ask!!! I am here to help you guys!!

Pascal or C or C++ or Java?

Pascal / C is ok. Tourist won IOI gold medals 6 times with Pascal.

C++ / Java comes with handy libraries and can make your life easier in some cases. C++ is preferred by most of the top competitive programmers in the world. Learning C++ is advisable. To learn C++ is easy, just read others source code on Codeforces; Search STL reference at http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/ :)

Happy Coding!
